document.text: with the power of selecting and ap pointing the members of the various committees, which committees un der those rules, passed on all pro posed legislation, framed the langu age of the bills, and practicall de cided whether or not legislation should be enacted by the House Under the present rule, the mem bers of the various committees are elected by a majority vote of tbe memberrs of the House. AJao, under tbe Cannon rnles, tbe Speaker was chairman of the power ful committee on rules, and since he bad the appointment of his brother members on that committee, he ac tually controlled the shaping aDd direction of all legislation brought before the House. Under the pre sent rales, not only is the Speaker shorn of bis former autocratic power to appoint members of com mittees, and thns to control the ac tion of the committees, bnt he him self is not permitted to be a member of the committee on roles. Not content with the above-men tioned changes, the House progres sives adopted certain rnles which changed the committees from arbi trary bodies to advisory bodies, and which greatly enlarged the power and influence of the individual members of the Honse. For in stance, under the Cannon rnles, the chairman of a committee could practically prevt a vote being taken on a measure which had been referred to bis committee while un der the prednt rules, although a committee cnairman is influential and powerful when it comes to shaping legislation coming before his committi e, he cannot prevent thy Honse from voting as to whet her or not a measure shall pass the House. The standpat Republicans, toget her with a few reactionary Demo crata, most of whom have since been retired to the shades of private life, fought hard againss the revision of the Cannon rnle, bnt tbey were overwhelmingly defeated, the new rnles were adopted, and Cannon- ism took its place among the things that used to be. In the fighting that preceded tbe final victories of the progressives in the lower Honse of Congress, Mr. Flood was always on the firing line, and he, together with Bepresenta tives A. Mitchell Palmer of Penn sylvania, Clande Kitchin of North Carolina, and James Hay of Vir ginia, ably assisted Bepresentative Oscar W. Underwood of Alabama in the bringing about of those pro gressive reforms that practically re stored to the people the power to shape legislation in the halls of Congress. Previously, when tbe Bepnbli- cans were in control of the Honse, Mr. Flood had frequently attacked the reactionaries who had entrench ed themselves behind the Gannon rnles, and on one occasion when the infamy of those rnles was under discussion on the floor of the Honse, particularly with reference to their application to a bill for the relief of the tobacco growers of Virginia, the member from the Tenth Dist rict, himself the author of a mea sure having for its purpose the re- ief of the Virginia growers, rose in his seat, and by the grace of Mr. Speaker Cannon, delivered a most forctble address in which he scored the antocratic power exercised by the Cannon regime, which, be re marked, had taken from the mem bers of the HonBe the powers dele gated to them by the Federal Con stitntion. Space does not permit me to give yon more than a taste of the milit ant progressivism with which that particular speech was charged, so 1 must content myself with quoting one small paragraph, reserving for my next weeks letter a fuller ac count of the speech, whioh itself alone stamps Henry D. Flood as one of that band of active progres sives whose efforts jrill be a step nearer fnll fruition when Woodrow Wil.on takes his sent in the White Honse. Mr. Flood said When Oliver Cromwell cleared ont liie Parliinent Honse with a file of soldier, it whb no whit more tyranmoal, no whit moie subversive sf the fundamental principles of representative government, than this aeeumptiou of a power which should only be exercised by a ma jority of -this Honse,namely tbe power to legislate. The above words are a matter of record. Tbey stamp the man who uttered them as the kind of fight ing progressive who counts. O b s e r v e r .

document.text: Will Tell House Rules Committee Of Deportation Work. Washington.  Attorney-General A. Mitchell Palmer will appear before the House Rules Committee this week to discuss the part he and his depart ment have played in the effort to de port undesirable aliens. Mr. Palmer and Representative Camp bell, chairman of the Rules Committee, were in conference. Palmer appeared at the committee rooms in response to a letter written him by Mr. Camp bell, in which Mr. Campbell pointed out that statements made by attorneys for Assistant Secretary of Labor Post might be considered a reflection upon the Attorney-General and the Depart ment of Justice. He suggested that Palmer should be given a chance to make a statement before the commit tee closed its hearings.

document.text: Whether Costs High, Low LINCOLN, NEB.The idea that the cost of living varies sharply from city to city doesnt carry much weight with the business-research bureau at the University of Neb raska. Living expenses are 12 per cent lower in New Orleans than in Wash ington, but those are the two ex tremes, the bureau reported. In 34 cities studied, the average differ ence amounted to less than 3 per cent, Dr. Edgar Z. Palmer, bureau chief, said. Food costs varied about Vi per cent. It seems to make little differ ence what city we live in, he said Living costs too much in any, and there is not much choice. Population appears to have no effect on living expenses, Palmer said.

document.text: We are asking all desiring to sing for our Lord, please join our choir. Mr. Jerry Wayne Davis, son of the late Mr. Charlie Edward Davis, of Appomattox, was married Saturday, December 5, at 2 p.m. to Miss Mary Rose Matthews, daughter of Mr. and- Mrs. George Rowland Matt hews of Appomattox. The double ring ceremony was performed by Rev. R. Q. Lawing Sr. A large number of relatives and friends witnessed the ceremony. Mr. Willie Harvey is receiv ing special treatment at LG ML Hospital. We extend our  sympathy to the family of Mr. Tommy Kelso. Let us pray with and for them. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Palmer spent their vacation in Balte more, Md. as guests of relatives and friends. The sick of our church and community are improving. A special talent program was successful at Promise Land. Many local churches were represented. Mrs. Thelma Hancock was the sponsor. In conclusion, let us think of helping others. See you in church.

document.text: Washington.-Tho wholesale liquor establishment, brother of tho bar, will be put to death May 16 under sen tence pronounced by Prohibition Com missioner Kramer. Although an opinion rendered by At torney-General Palmer last December said the wholesaler had no legal right to continue in business, Internal Rev enue and prohibition officials decided to grant some time In which he could unload stocks without too heavy mon etary loss. But Mr. Kramers an nouncement mtfde It clear there would be no further extension of time and that execution of tho sentence would be carried out. Mr. Kramer, however, opened the way for the retail druggist to obtain supplies for prescriptions, removing the Imn on withdrawals from bonded warehouses. For sevoral months such warehouse doors have been closed. The order makes it possible for the retail druggist to transact business direct with the bonded warehçuses Wholesae druggists will be taken care of later. Mr. Kramer Indicated, by granting them similar privileges. Dealings between retail druggists and other purchasers and the bonded warehouses later will be limited by regulations which officials declared would be drastic enough to satisfy the I most ardent dry advocate. They must  be based, however, It was added, on  Mr. Palmers opinion. It Is planned to put them In effect about the time the wholesale houses go out of exist ence. So far aB the wholesaler Is con cerned, Mr. Kramer said, his one task now is to get rid of the stocks on hand. He will not be allowed to in crease his present holdings, but there are no strings, tied, to him .In selling 18druggists, either wholesale or lé tau, before May 15. Officials an nounced no Agures concerning the amount of liquor held by the whole salers, but said they believed the stocks largely would be disposed of before the doors are closed finally. Prohibition officials declined to com ment on the statement in Pblladel phla of former Attorney General Pal mer, who said his recent ruling that physicians may prescribe beer might mean that beer could be sold over soda fountain counters Regulations carrying out Mr. Palmers opinion! handed down the day before he retired from office, will be left to the next Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said Commissioner Williams, adding that therefore the full effect of the opinion could not now be determined. The Revenue and Prohibition bu reaus have been besieged since the Palmer opinion was made public, both wets and drys urging their sides for consideration of the officials In draft lng the regulations. Although consid erable study has been given to the ruling, there was no indication that the regulations could be completed short of another 10 days.

document.text: WASHINGTON.Secretary of In terior Julius P. Krug has announced that 45,000 acres in Alaskas Mata nuska .valleynear the ghost town of Knikwould be opened to home steading next spring. . The district land office at Anchor age will start accepting applications from war veterans October 17. The general public can apply after next January 15. Actual settlement will be permitted six months after appli cations are approved. Krug said most of the land is un improved but suitable for farming. This is in contrast with 2,750,000 acres of public land along the Alaska highway, upon which settlement, may begin  October 2. The newly opened highway, lands are non-agri- cultural.  The new Matanuska homesteads may not exceed 160 acres. The land is free. There is a filing fee of 5 for tracts not larger than 80 acres and 10 for tracts of 81 acres or more, plus a commission of 1.50 for each 40 acres. The proposed homesteads are in the Wasilla-Goose Bay region, in the northeastern end of Knik Arm, 48 miles from Palmer, headquarters of the Alaska Rural Rehabilitation corporation farm cooperative proj ect, or 15 minutes by plane from Anchorage The Alaska railroad crosses the northern end of the area. .. Krug said the decision to open the area to settlement was based on land classification reports showing that the area was suitable for farm ing and is needed for further devel opment of the valley. The bureau of land management said the area is sparsely settled, partially because the original Mata nuska development in 1935 drew settlers away from the Wasilla- Goose B s v region.

document.text: Washington.Four new moVss were made here in the wet and dry con troversy, revived and inflamed by the Palmer decision that the prohibition enforcement officers cannot prohibit or limit physicians prescriptions for beer for medicinal purpose. They were President Harding was told in a conference at the White House by Wayne B. Wheeler that the Anti- Saloon League would not stand for a Commissioner of Internal Revenue with a wet record. The solicitor of the Internal Rev enue Bureau rendered a decision hold ing that the prohibition unit cannot collect a beverage tax on liquor pur chased by a druggist if it is stolen or destroyed, and the Department of Justice has upheld him. A light wine and beer backfire prop aganda campaign, through a chain of postcards, was started on Congress. In the Supreme Court the validity of the prohibition amendment was at tacked on the ground that the section making the amendment inoperative unless ratified in seven years violates Article V of the Constitution, which gives Congress no power to impose a limit on ratification or to otherwise attempt to control what the Legisla tures of the States shall do In their deliberaions. Mr. Wheeler called at the White House to make clear the attitude of the prohibitionists. document.text: Washington.Beer and wines are given the same status as whisky un der an opinion by the Attorney Gen eral just made public by the Bureau of Internal Revenue. The ruling, one of the most import ant since the advent of national pro hlbition, makes it possible for all alco holic liquors to be used for medical and other nombeverage purposes, and for all to be manufactured and sold for these purposes subject only to the limitations of the Volstead Act on nonbeverage intoxicants. The opinion was written by former Attorney General Palmer the day bé fore he retired from office, and was in reply to a series of questions from internal revenue and prohibition offi cials bearing on construction of half a dozen moot points in the law. t There are many rumors afloat that the opinion had wrecked plans of dry advocates of liquor sales. Officials re fused to comment on the reports, how ever, but Wayne B. Wheeler, general counsel of the Anti-saloon League is sued a statement in which he said that 39 States had State codes pro hibiting the prescribing of beer for medicinal purposes. Mr Wheeler de clared the opinion was not in accord with -the purpose of the Federal law. Congress clearly did not intend to attempt to legalize what the State laws prohibit, Mr. Wheeler said Unless the opinion is overruled Con gress should amend thé law. It is difficult, of course, to overrule it be cause the Government and the brew ers are on the same side of the case and there is no one to contest it un less the new Attorney General over rules the opinion. The opinion appeared ambiguous in some respects, officials said, and as a result they were unable to determine whether the government had power. In the Hght of the ruling, to limit the number of prescriptions which a phy sician may write, except that the law specifies no more than a pint per per son in a ten-day period. Mr. Palmer declared he believed it the purpose of Congress to leave the physician unfettered by governmental control, yet he thought that regulations might properly restrict the amount to be sold on any one prescription. Mr. Palmer called attenion to pro visions of law which, apparently, had left the physician to act on his judg ment. He suggested then that when a physician abused the privilege he could be dealt with criminally, but added that In no case should the judg ment of the physician be supplanted by that of enforcement officials, a situation he -believed would result from regulations attempting to con trol the use of prescriptions. Replying to the question whether the Government could restrict the number, of permits to manufacture, sell or prescribe in any State or com munity, Mr. Palmer explained that the Volstead Act had limited only the classes to which permits could be issued and had permitted no discrimi nation between persons within those classes. He said the withholding of permits could not be done legally, even though officials were convinced that fewer permits would suffice in any given State or city. Mr. Palmer advised officials that they had ample authority to writ1? such regulations as -they believed necessary to make certain the en forcement of the law. Dry advocates stressed this statement, declaring that by It means would be found which would circumvent and handi cap sale of beer and wines and would not throw open the door to manu facture of quantities of high alcoholic beer again as anti-prohibitionists in sisted.

document.text: Washington.Attorney-General Pal mer will take up the question of gov ernmental action in the soalled out law railroad strike immediately. Offi cials of the Department of Justice were busy Sunday assembling detailed reports, gathered by telephone and telegraph from all important strike centers. Action can be taken by the Govern ment under the Lever act, in the pres ent case, it was said. There was a slight hint, however, that in event Mr. Palmer decided to throw the weight of the Government into the con troversy, it would not be by the in junction process which was the meth od employed in the bituminous coal strike. Officials apparently favor the use of the criminal indictment to check the power of the so-called out laws. If the Government moves to end the strike by authority of the Lever act, it was indicated -the basis would be a charge that the flow of food shipments had been stopped, or hindered at least. Although the provisions of the Lever act make It possible to charge a con spiracy, it was believed that by whole sale indictment of individuals the strike could be ended more quickly than through the lodging of con spiracy charges against the strike leaders.

document.text: Washington.- .-Proceedings asking Out Balnbridge Colby, secretary of ,tste be enjoined from issuing any proclamation declaring the suffrage mendment ratified, were -instituted in the District of Columbia Supreme Court by Charles S. Fairchield, of jew York, president of the Ameri ca Constitutional League. Mr. Fairchild also seeks to prevent Attorney General Palmer from en forcing the amendment. Justice Bailey issued a rule on Secretary Col ly and the Attorney General to Show aause July 13 why the motion should sot be granted. The basis of the proceedings is the claim that the ratification of the amendment by the West Virginia Legislature was illegal because ac complished by fraud and that the proposed mtlficaitiiian toy the Tennessee Legislature also would be illegal on tie ground that the legislature lacked authority under the states constitu tion to act on the measure. Only 35 states have ratified the amendment, and as ratification by one other is necessary the attack on tie amendments through the courts at this time came as a surprise In wffrage circles here. An attack on the legality of the action of the Ten nessee legislature had been expected, but not until the legislature actually had acted. In anticipation of such a move by the anti-suffrage forces, the organiza tions supporting the amendment have arged early action by more than 36 states so that the amendment could become operative in time to permit ! the omen to vote In the4presiden- ! dal election this year.  Application for the restraining or der was said by the National Wom ans Party, in a statement, to indi cate the bitterness of the opposition  to suffrage and the determination  ol its opponents to defeat the oto- I tiouswlll of states which have signi fied their approval of the enfranchise-  sent of the women of the nation. ... We are convinced that, as In the  Ohio referendum case, said the j Womans Party statement, the  validity of the action of the various  Hate legislatures in ratifying the suf- i Inge amendment will finally be up held by the courts. Anti-suffragists  are evidently grasping at straws in  their attempt through court proceed- i lags to lengthen the suffrage strug- ! fie and to force the expenditure of more money and time by suffragists lor the success of their cause.

document.text: Washington.- on charges of high I crimes and misdemeanors, Federal I Judge K. M Landis, of Chicago, was I impeached in the House of Representa I lives bv Representative Welty Demo- I crat of Ohio, because of his accept- I ance of the office of supreme arbitrator I of baseball while still serving on the I bench. In taking this step the Ohio mem- I ber swept aside an opinion by Attor- I ney General Palmer that Judge Lan- I dis was within the law and that there I was no law making such acceptance I a crime, either misdemeanor or fel- I ony. The opinion was rendered re- I cently by the Attorney General on the I written request of Mr. Welty, who I had questioned the Judges right to I hold both positions. I Before proceeding to the floor of I the House, where his charges were I read, Mr. Welty refused a request by I Senator Dial Democrat of South I Carolina, to include in the general  Indictment statements attributed to  Judge Landis in refusing to send to I Jail a young Ottawa 111. bank clerk I because of the Judges belief th a t1 officials of the bank were responsible  for the clerks peculation by failure j to pay him a living wage. Senator Dial, on receiving the Ohio j representatives refusal, announced he would file complaint against Judge Landis with the Department of Justice,  and late in the day attacked the Chicago jurist on the floor of the Sen-  ate, describing him as a freak and a  crank. The South Carolina Senator i i characterized Judge Landis state-, ment that the Ottawa bank clerks   employers were, in a measure, re sponsible for the youths theft of 96,000 as the most bolshevik doctrine I ever heard. and added that if the action taken by the judge in paroling the clerk is to be encouraged, it is striking at the foundations of our gov ernment. There was no comment in the House when Mr. Welty concluded the reading of a formal indictment of Judge Lan dis. On his own motion, as is customary In such proceedings, the indictment was referred to the Judiciary Com mittee without debate. Less than a third of the members present voted, and a number of scattering voices were lifted in opposition. Nobody asked for a rising vote. Representa tive Sherwood, Democrat, of Ohio, sit ting on the front row, clapped his hands, hut otherwise there was no in dication as to how the House felt. The next step will be by Mr. Welty, who will appear, possibly this week, before the Judiciary Committee, with such witnesses as he sees fit to call, to amplify his charges. The commit tee will then decide whether to go ahead with the case. It has the power to dismiss the charges and so report to the House, and adoption of such a report would exonerate Judge Landis of the charges preferred by Mr. Welty. Belief was expressed in House circles that the case would be thrown out by the committee, in view of the opinion by the Attorney General. In that event the end would come before adjournment of Congress on March 4. Adjournment, however, would not stop proceedings should the committee find enough evidence to send the case on to the House. The impeachment proceedings the Judiciary Committee acts in a simi lar capacity to a justice of the peace. The House -s the grand jury, and if the House indicts it transmits its find- lnP t0 the Senate, which becomes the trial court. It requires only a ma jority vote for the House to indict, hut a two-thirds vote by the Senate is necessary to convict.

document.text: Washington, D. C.Framers of the American Income Tax Law are not worried by the capitalist fugitives who are expatriating themselves to escape the tax. Leaders said Representative Underwood If It be true that American millionaires are seeking asylum in England to escape the American Income tax, they will be hurt more than they now know. I think there must be another reason why they should seek the sovereignty of Great Britain, and it might be in their love for a monarchy over their iove for a republic. Representative Hull, Tennessee framer of the Income Tax Law The American tax on small incomes is less than Englands tax. It is less, in fact, than the income tax levy by any Eu ropean country, and the American who vents his resentment on this country because of its new income tax law will have to flee to some uncivilized coun try to escape payment of this tax. I have no sympathy with any one who has made his money in this country and who seeks to evade payment of lust taxation. Representative Rainey, Illinois We can better afford to lose than to hold those of our rich who are fleeing to foreign countries to escape taxation. We have their property and their agents will pay this countrys levies. It is a good riddance. Representative Sabath, Illinois No American who has lived and knows eondltiohs in foreign countries where Income taxes are levied will flee the Income tax of the United States. If he does the protection of this coun try should be withdrawn, because we do not want him. Representative Palmer, Pennsyl vania The income tax has come to stay in this country. Our millionaires will learn to conform to its require ments. Those Americans who are living abroad will find they will have to pay an income tax and they will learn its burden is heavier than the tax imposed by this country.

document.text: Washington, D. C. Special.Thou sands of his fellow-citizens turned out to welcome President Roosevelt to the national capital, and made his home coming an occasion for an ovation from the time he was sighted on the plat form of his car until he passed within the doors of the White House. There was no band of music, but the sweeter melody of the cheers of the assembled people made the air ring with hurrahs as his carriage passed slowly up the avenue. It was awfully kind of them to come out to greet me, the President remarked to some friends at the White House por tecochcre, and I was deeply, deeply touched by their welcome. The presidential train came into the station at 619 oclock. On the platform were assembled a dozen or more officials. At their head was Mr. West, the Dis trict Commissioner, who was in charge of the arrangements for the welcome, and who was the first to shake the Pres idents hand as he stepped from the train. With the President were his sec retary of state, Mr. Root, and Mrs. Root and the secretary of the treasury, Mr, Shaw. At the station were Secretary Hitchcock, Postmaster General Cortelyou Mr. Quesada, the Cuban minister Dr. Rixey, the surgeon general of the Navy Mr. Palmer, the marshal for the Dis trict of Columbia, and others. A mighty cheer went up as the crowd inside the depot caught sight of the President, which was taken up by the crowds outside of the station and passed along the line as the President was recognized. He shook hands first with the Cabinet members and other officials. Then, giving Mrs. Roosevelt his arm, he walked slowly to his carriage, which was waiting at the Sixth street entrance. As he reached the engine the President thanked the engineer for his safe trip and stopped to shake his hand. In the car riage with the President were Mrs, Roosevelt, Ethel, Kermit and Quentin Quentin sat on the box with the coach man. The cabinet officers and the other mem bers of the party followed in carriages, accompanying the President to the White House. The President frequently arose and bowed to the cheering crowds on both sides of the Avenue, and, during the latter part of the drive, the hur rahs became so enthusiastic that the President stood most of the time. Mrs Roosevelt was greatly pleased with the greeting, and her face was radiant as she bowed to the right and left. Not since last inauguration day has Pennsylvania avenue held such a crowd as lined.it from the station to the White House. Heavy cables, stretched the whole length on both sides, kept the crowds on the sidewalks. Street cars were stopped and vehicles were halted in thé side streets as the party came up the avenue. From every flagpole and from many windows flags were flapping in the cool evening breeze. A brilliant scene greeted the Presi dents eye as he reached the White House. The mansion was illuminated from basement to attic, bathing the whole white structure in a soft, radiant glow. As the President reached the White House gate he stopped his carriage, and, lifting his hat to the crowd, said  Good night, good luck and thank you so much for all this.

document.text: Washington, D. C. Representative Francis Burton Harrison, of New York, was nominated to be Governor-General of the Philippines to succeed W. Cameron Forbes. .Mr. Harrison is oqe of the leading members of the Ways and Means Com mittee and a stanch A dm inistration supporter in the House. His appointment was strongly urged by Majority Leader Underwood and Caucus Chairman A. Mitchel! Palmer. It was also welcomed by the advo cates In Congress of the immediate independence of the islands. Mr. Har rison, in the past, has been outspoken in bis championship of independence for the Filipino people. The retirement of Mr. Harrison from the House assures the election of Mr. Palmer to the chairmanship of the Ways and Means Committee and therefore to the majority leadership, should Representative Underwood be elected tq the Senate from Alabama. As Governor-General of the Philip pines, Mr. Harrison will receive a salary of 15,000 a year aud an addi tional sum of 5,000 a year as presi dent. of the Philippine Commission. This is more money than is paid to any official of tiie Government with the exception of the President. Am bassadors receive 17,500 a year, Cabinet members 12.000 and Minis ters to foreign governments, 10.000 a year. The Governor of the Panama Canal Zone receives 14.000 a year. Mr. Harrison is perhaps the wealthiest member of the House and tne salary feature of the new job had no weight with him. He accepted the appointment, he told friends, because he believ-d there was much important work to be done in the islands. He wants to reorganize the whole Philip pine Government and prepare the peo ple of that Oriental archipelago for self-government as soon as it is pos sible. The declarations in the Baltimore platform in favor of Philippine inde pendence, the views of the President upon this question and the declared position of Mr. Harrison upon it lead to the belief that the Philippines will at least be given an opportunity of home rule before this Administration is ended.

document.text: Washington.  The new War In dustries Board held its first conference with President Wilson Monday and took up in general the problems it must face in the purchase of war sup plies for this government and the Allies. The President indicated his idea of the boards functions. , One of the points decided was that the Allies of the United States should be given the same advantages in the purchases of war materials as this country enjoys. Members of the board are Frank Scott, Bernard M. Baruch, Hugh Frayne, Robert S. Brookings, L. S. Lovett, Lieutenant Colonel Palmer E. Pierce and Rear Admiral Frank F. Fletcher. Secretary Daniels also at tended the conference. , J The question of co-ordinating Ameri can and allied purchases will be one of the first to be taken up by the board. Allied purchases soon will be made by Bernard Baruch, who is to be designated by the allied governments as their buying commissioner. At the same time he will be chairman of a purchasing commission for the Ameri can government to be formed of mem- bers of the War Board, with Herbert  Hoover as a member in charge of food purchases. Officials believe that ultimately a j system may be evolved under which one man will do all the Atnerican and allied buying, members of the War Board serving as advisers. Legisla tion would be required, however, be fore the government departments could delegate purchases to any person out side of their organizations. For the present American purchases will be negotiated by the buying com mission, but contracts for the Army and Navy will be signed by their rep resentatives on the War Board. Ship ping Board purchases probably will be made by the buying commission itself, as there Is no legal obstacle. The board faces a considerable problem in obtainingsupplies for the Allies at the same price paid by the American government. Already the proposal has brought protests from manufacturers and producers who have agreed to sell to this government at prices lower than.the market.

In the hope of learning more about the mysterious region of multi-colored lakes sighted from the air in Antarctica last year, the United States navy has started a special expedition to the area. The first of two ships chosen for the taskthe icebreaker Edisto  sailed receitly from Norfolk, Va. A second iceineaker, the Burton Is land, saileefrom San Pedro, Calif. Each vesseig to carry a helicopter, to permit nyy fliers to land hi the lake region,among the gravel hills that precluq a landing by a con ventional aiplane. Comdr. Grald L. Ketchum was designated t head the expedition, it was learnf. The two icebreakers will rendezvqg at sea, it was indi cated, and loceed directly to the Antarctic iceiack. Operie in Summer. The plan ohxploration adopted is for the two iibreakers to drive as near to the oast as possible and launch their llicopters. Although it will be wintefn the northern hemi sphere, the eedition will have the advantage oftperating during the Antarctic sumer. Personnel will live aboard th Edisto and the Bur ton Island, adding the difficulties of setting up base ashore, as was done by last jxrs larger navy ex pedition. Plans for a tit to Little America were tentative but it was under stood that su a visit might be made. In addon, It was learned that the expedim might attempt to force the ice brier at other points where explorah has been slight, provided time mains after it has accomplished i primary mission of studying theike area. A primary nrtery surrounding this region is w the lakes do not freeze, surround as they are by glaciers and pertual snow. document.text: Views of a Globe Girdler. Charles J. Glidden, the globe gird ling automobilist, wrote to some Boston friends as follows concerning his impressions of the first part of his Journey from Boston to Mexico by road and railroad tracks Six years ago I drove over the road from Bos ton to New York, and considerable Improvement was noticed on this trip hut on the average the road can be considered only fair, in comparison with the good roads around Boston and the excellent roads of France Closed roads necessitated detours in Connecticut, increasing the distance twenty miles, and the roads we were obliged to take were wretched. The trouble and expense we have been put to in arranging for our permits and numbers for New Jersey, Pennsyl- vania and Maryland give the impres sion that we are not in a united coun try, but driving through small coun tries in Europe. Special numbers, 1 am informed, are not required in other States. Motoring can be made ideal between New York and Boston by improving the roads in Connecti cut and Massachusetts east of Palmer and south of Springfield to the State line.New York Sun.

It was read amid aa almost continuous storm of ap plause, And was adopted unanimously with out a Word of debate. When the nominations for President were called for, it was apparent that Palmer Would be nominated over hto protest, as the opposition to Bragg had concentrated upon birth These two names wero tbe only ones pre sented to the convention. It was known that 11 message from President Cleveland had reached tho convention that ho could not en tertain for a moment the suggestion of bis cwn nomination, and bis decision was at once accept d as final, Before tho states wofe called for nominations, Henry Watter- son was taken out of the lists by Mr. Carroll, of Louisville, wbo, from tho platform, con veyed to tbe convention a message from the Kentucky editor In his retreat in the moun tains of Switzerland. Mr. Watorson, Mr, Carroll said, three days after the Chicago convention had cabled that other candidates must bo named or the Democracy was lost. Later he had Bald he Jld not want tbe honor, bat that if no one ilse could be found to take command, ho would not UBk others to go where be Would not lead. Now that others were ready to accept, he preferred to do bnttlo In the ranks Some of the nominating speeches wore eloquent and full of fire. L . L . Kllbourn, of Michigan, placed Senator Palmer in nomina tion and there was a scries of seconding speeches. Burr W. Jones, of Wisconsin, aoair oted General Bragg,  the hero of 0 battles and the commander of tho Iron Brigade. Illinois waited untill all the other states had been called. Then Judge Morno, of Chicago, took the stage and said they had lecegnizod from the first that Senator Pal mer wns tbe man to lead the fight. He was, Qe said, a platform in himBelf. All hto life he had fought fialism, greenbacktom, free diver and other vagaries. But he had aealod nelr lips. After securing the temper of tbe tonVentlon, however, he said Illinois was compelled to join bauds with her sister states n urging hto nomination. The roll call immediately developed an verwbelmlug majority in favor of Senator Palmer, but It proceeded to tbe end, lalmef ecelvlng 757X votes and Bragg 124. - At is conclusion the commander of the -rob Brigade mounted a chair and, in A brief but graceful speech, moved that the nomina tion be made unanimous, nnd pledged that bo and Wisconsin in the coming battle would be where brake soldiers should always be icarest the flashing of the guns. He was given three hearty cheers, and General Pal mer was declared the nominee amid an ehthusinstlcdemonstration, during which the sste guidons were carried about tbo hall in the wake of the standard of Illinois. Thero never wns any doubt about General Buckners nomination for Vice-President,  ixccpt while the nomination was being talked of for Sonaor Palmer for President. When Chairman Caffrey Instructed tbe secretary to call the Slates for nomination for Vice-President, tho latter called but one 8a,  Kentucky, and tbe band struck up My Old Kentucky Home. William F. Brodder, of Bussellvtlle, Ky., placed General Buckners name formerly in nomination and the nomination was forthwith made unanimous. After the convention had adjourned Senator Pal mer sucoumbod. He said he would ac cept. He had never yet failed to respond to the call ct duty, he said, and he oouldnot do so now with such a cause at stake.

It is the most sweeping anti- !  trust action ever brought by the De- I i pariment of Justice. The government asks not only for the dissolution of the United States j ! Steel Corporation, but for the dlssolu- j tion of all constituent or subsidiary companies which axe alleged to have I combined in violation a l the Sherman law to maintain, or attempt to main-  tain a monopoly of the steel business. j There axe 36 subsidiary corporations j named as defendants. This j j action of the directors was taken but I a few hours before the filing of the j I bill. The government acknowledges I that it was advised of the steel cor-  j porations intention in this respect, j I but states that under the terms of the j  lease no cancellation would be effec-  tive until January 1, 1915, and there I is no limit upon the amount of ore j that can be taken out in the meantime. I Sensational allegations fairly topple i over each other in the governments J  petition, which is an equity proceed-! So serl- rlous is the threat of a fuel famine that Governor Lowden of niinols urged the authorities at Washington to act quick ly in bringing about a settlement. In the national capital it was said Sec retary of Labor Wilson was about to make a report to the president Mr. Tumulty, secretary to President Wil son, said a satisfactory solution of tho problem would be reached -through the efforts of Attorney General Palmer, who named a committee to fix profit margins, and the orders of the inter state commerce commission. Others were not nearly so optimistic as Mr, Tumulty.

document.text: This Was the Vote on the Repeal B illThe Final Vote on the Voorhees B ill for Uncondi tional Repeal Was Taken on Monday NightDaniel Votes in the Negative and Hunton in the Affirmative. When the Senate met on Monday morning, 52 Senators answered to their names when the roll was called. As soon as the Vice President en tered the Chamber, at 11 a. m., he an nounced that the Senate resume its session, and thatHouse bill No. 1 the silver purchase repeal bill was now before the Senate. Mr. Hunton, of Virginia, explained briefly the position which he had oc cupied, and still occupied, ou the re peal hill. He subscribed in good faith to the Chicago platform, which demanded the repeal of the Sherman law. He should vote for its repeal. But he stood ready to joip his silver friends in a fight. for silver, and strive earnestly and manfully for vic tory. Senators Morgan, Jones, of Nevada Cockrell, Vest, Carey, and others, anti-repeal, occupied the time in speech-making until 430, when sev eral amendments were offered and voted down, then Mr. Jones, of Ne vada, resumed the floor. At 645 Mr. Jones finished his speech, and Mr. Peffer began speak ing, saying he would occupy only 15 minutes of the time of the Senate. He was correct-as to the time, fin ishing at 7 oclock. Mr. Harris spoke ten minutes, and was followed by Mr. Stewart, who began_ with the prefa tory remark that the die is cast. , Mr. Stewart closed at 720 and then the Vice-President stated that if no further amendment was offered the vote would now be taken on the engrossment and third reading of the bill. That was agreed to without a division, and then the vote was taken hy yeas and nays on the passage of the bill as amended, and it was passed. Yeas 43 nays 32, as follows YeasAldrich, Brice, Caffery,Cam den, Carey, Cullom, Davis, Dixon, Dolph, Faulkner, Frye, Gallinger, GibsSn, Gorman, Gray, Hale, Haw ley, HigginB, Hill, Hoar, Hanson, Lindsay, Lodge, McMillan, McPher son, Manderson, Mills, Mitchell, of Wisconsin Morrill, Murphy, Platt Proctor, Quay, Ransom, Sherman, Smith, Squire, stockbridge, Turpie, Vilas, Voorhee8? Washburn and White43. NaysAllen, Bate, Berry, Black burn, Butler, Call Cameron, Cock rell, Coke, Daniel, Dubois, George, Harris, Irby, Jones, Arkansas, Jones, Nevada Kyle, Martin, Pasco, Peffer, Perkins,  Pettigrew, Power, Pugh, Roach, Shoup, Stewart, Teller, Vance, Vest, Walthal and Wolcoot 32. The following were the pairs Mitchell, Oregon, and Allison Chandler and White, California Colquit and Wilson Palmer and Hansbrough Gordan and Morgan. As soon as the vote was announced the Senate at 750 p. m. adjourned till tomorrow at noon. Tomorrow the Secretary Of the Senate will appear at the bar of the House with a message, informing that body that the bill has been passed, with an amendment, and re questing the concurence of the House in that amendment. The message and billmay remain on the speakers desk until it is convenient to have it laid before the body, or it may be re ferred to a committee, or the Senate amendment may be concurred in without reference to any committee and by a direct vote of the House. Not only was the repeal bill brought to a termination today, but so also was the abnormally long legislative day of Tuesday, the 17th of October. The Senate will meet tomorrow at noon and the session will be opened with prayer and the usual formalities.

document.text: There are only two requirements for making Who Was Who in Amer ica, an additional volume to Whos Who. They are death and a listing in Whos Who in Amer ica itsef, since the new 1,406-page Who Was Who contains the non living listed in Whos Who from its founding in 1897 up to the cur rent edition. Approximately 800 names will hereafter become eligi ble annually for succeeding Who Was Who volumes. At present a viscount, eight Presi dents of the United States, a premier of a republic the government of which is now in exile, and- 27,447 others meet the two reo.uirements for listing in Who Was Who. The viscount is William Waldorf Astor. The eight Presidents are Cleveland, Coolidge, Harding, Har rison, McKinley, Theodore Roose velt, Taft and Wilson. And the pre mier is Ignace Jan Paderewski, fa mous pianist and composer, who had a leading part in organizing the Po lish republic in 1919. Dates From Civil War. Among the 27,447 others whose sketches as last published in Whos Who now reappear in Who Was Who with the dates of their deaths added, are American leaders from Civil war days to the present. This long span which the volume covers brings famous figures of past dec ades such as Alexander Graham Bell, Sarah Bernhardt, Chauncey Depew, Anna Held, Mme. Nellie Mel ba, Potter Palmer, James Whitcomb Riley and Mark Twain, into its pages beside leaders of recent years like Jane Addams, Sherwood Anderson, William E. Borah, Louis D. Bran déis, Arthur Brisbane, Thomas A. Edison, Daniel Frohman, George W. Goethals and Robert M. LaFollette. One, that of a woman, mentions relief work on battlefields during the Civil war and the organization at her own expense of searches for missing men. It is the last Whos Who sketch of Clara Barton, first presi dent of the American Red Cross. Another lists employment in 1860 as a pony express rider. It is Buf falo Bill Codys sketch. Sketch Successes. Many of the sketches are strik ing examples of the opportunity this country has offered for exceptional advancement and achievement. A typical sketch of this type, beginning with farm work and clerking for four years, ends with a mention of a mil- lion-dollar gift to a museum. It is Marshall Fields. Other business men whose sketches recall intimate details of unusually interesting commercial and industrial careers are those of James C. Fargo, whose enterprise became the American Express com pany Robert Dollar, who started in a lumber camp and became one of the worlds leaders in ocean ship ping Harvey Firestone, who began with 17 employees in the rubber business and finally employed 40,000 Edward Harriman, clerk who be came railroad king  Henry Flag ler, another clerk who personally owned 600 miles of railroad before he died Julius Rosenwald, who started in the wholesale clothing business but bought control of a struggling mail order business Sears, Roebuck and Co.which had to have clothing to fulfill some of its advertising offers John H. Patter son, who perfected the cash regis ter, but started in the coal business and Theodore N. Vail, for many years president of the American Telephone and Telegraph company, I who first studied medicine. MacArthurs Dad in Book. General Arthur MacArthurs name ! is in both Whos Who and Who j Was Who, since it appears in his famous sons current Whos Who - biography. Gen. Nelson A. Miles  records that in 1864 he commanded an army corps of 26.000 men at 25 years of age. Henry Clews, the financier, who recorded in his sketch that during the Civil war the secretary of the treasury in Lincolns cabinet placed him in charge of the sale of bonds for continuing the war, and as well that later General Grant -recom mended him as advisor to Japan in setting up its financial system, also reported that he had originally studied for the ministry. Oliver Wendelf Holmes, the jurist, carefully- detailed his Civil war wounds anatomicallyin the chest at Balls Bluff, in the neck at Antietam, in the foot at Marys Hillbefore de scribing his succeeding legal experi ence and writings. John Hay noted that his earliest employment was as one of Abraham Lincolns secre taries, while John D. Rockefeller re corded his initial job as clerking ip a commission and forwarding busi ness.

After lying on the bottom of Black- water river over four months the body of 14 -vear-old Tracey Blount, son of Peter Blount, of Smithfield, came to the surface and was found floating near Zuni, I by Lee Urquhart. The boys father had I advertised in several papers offering a reward for the lad, whose disappearance had mystified all his friends, but no clue to his fate had come to light until Wed nesday. Tracey was seen rear Zuni sit ting on a bridge over the river on No vember 22 , 1904 . He is supposed to have fallen or jumped into the water and been drowned at that time. Because his father refused to let him go riding, the four-year-old son of C. W. Huffman, of Chester, attempted to burn his fathers house. He was whipped and put to bed, but got loose and set fire to the barn, which was burned, in volving a loss of  1 . 000 . While she was in the field with her brother burning corn stalks bear Savage grossing, 6 -year-old Eva Brinkley was varned from her shoulders to her knees. Her skin was badly scorched. Dr. Harre, the attending physician, thinks she cannot recover. In his efforts to stay he flames Evas 14 -year-old brother Floyd was seriously burned about the hands and arms. The 14 -year-old daughter of a farmer nyned McHaynie, of Northumberland county, was badly injured, her clothing taking fire while burning brush. While blazing she drew water from a well and her mother extinguished the blaze. W. H. Loving, a prosperous young farmer who lived near Bowling Green, Caroline county, blew his head off wtih a shotgun. He was alone and his body Was not found until some time later. Loving was a great sufferer from dys pepsia. This probably caused his sui cide. The Department of Public Instruction has issued notices that the yearly ex amination of white teachers will be held at various points July 19 and 20 and for colored teachers July 21 and 22 . Secretary Frank P. Brent, of the State Board of Education, said that the Board would likely soon make a reply to the charges of J. D. Eggleston, Jr., who gave figures fo show that Virginia school patrons are being compelled to pay exor bitant prices for their books. Mr. Brent characterizes some of Mr. Egglestons statements as misleading. An investi gation, however, indicates that the State has spent thousands of dollars for teach ers registers, which are printed by the J. L. Hill Printing Company of Rich mond. The lowest price at which they can be obtained.in lots of 100  is 60 cents a copy. The regular price is 75 cents. Three responsible firm are said to be ready to print these hooks at from 18 to 25 cents each. The heavy winds blew down an un finished two-story frame structure in the southeastern section of Roanoke which was owned by W. H. Carter, who ex pected to opei a drug store when the building was completed. It was com pletely demolished, the loss being about  2 , 000 . No one was injured, but Mrs. J. W. Snedyar was miraculously saved. A letter was delivered to her a few mo ments before as she was at work be side the building that collapsed. As she stepped into her home to read the letter the crash came. Palmer St. Clair, trainmaster on the Radford division of the Norfolk and Western, who recently resigned to be come superintendent of the Mathieson aikali works, at Saltville, was elected president of the company, which is capitalize at over  1 , 000 . 000 . Mr. Robert W. Burke, president of the National Valley Bank and one of Staun tons most substantial citizens, died in that city, aged 67 years. Mr. Burke found it necessary a year ago to underge a surgical operation at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, after which he was greatly improved for a while. document.text: The Youth Committee of the Appomattox Baptist Associa tion will be showing the movie MY SON, MY SON on Saturday evening, Oct. 4. at the Appomattox County High School auditorium at 730 p.m. The public is invited to attend. In a day when many Christian parents search for answers, this film offers some needed suggestions and guide lines. It is the true story of Bernard Palmer and his son Barry. After Barrys mother died his father rem arried. Barry rejected his stepmother and as he grew older he rebelled in many ways. Barrys behaviour brought heartache and em barassm ent to the Palmer household. Post - midnight telephone calls, humi liating visits to the local jail, and the inevitable community gossip were hard to bear. Maybe you can identify with such difficult parent-child rela tions and you would like to see what happened to Barry Palmer. Well, it was only after the pursuit of his rebellion had all but swung full course before Barry, like the prodigal Son, come to the end of himself and realized he must haye a new beginning. It was the realiza tion of that new beginning in Gods love and forgiveness found in Jesus the Christ that brought Good News to the Palm ers Life. Maybe you would like such an experience in your family relationship also. We encourage you and invite you to come and see with us this great story of Gods gift of

document.text: The strike on the Interborough Rapid Transit Companys lines in New York is at an end, the men having been ad vised by the leaders to apply for rein statement. A man known as Hunter de Bowie is accused in New York of various swin dling operations in which women were the victims. Young Kingdon Gould was hazed by The Black Avengers of Columbia Col lege. The committee of the Trunk Line As sociation in charge of the uniform bill of lading question has agreed to with draw the hill, to which objection has been made, if the shippers will promise to drop the appeal to the Interstate Com merce Commission. Chairman J. Taylor Ellyson, of the Virginia Democratic State Committee, is expected by many to resign some time in May. William W. Conner, of Somerset coun ty, Md., committed suicide at Norfolk. Norfolk supervisors paid back into the treasury 4,815 salaries paid to them in excess of the 30 allowed. The National Mothers Congress is expected to demand the unseating of Senator Smoot, of Utah. Six colonels in the army are soon to be retired with the rank of brigadier-gen eral. Sir H. Rider Haggard was the guest of the President at the White House. For the present the President will consider no more applications for con sular positions. Grand Chief Stone, of the Brother hood of Locomotive Engineers, revoked the charter of the striking Interborough engineers in New York. Many of the strikers applied at the companys offices for positions. The strike continues. Representative members of the theat rical profession attended the funeral of Mr. A. M. Palmer in the Little Church Around the Corner in New York. Albert De Rome, crippled from the effects of hazing, swore out warrants for the arrest of students of the Hopkins Art Institute, in San Francisco. By a collision at Monk Center, Ind., between two trains Engineer Harson was fatally injured and Fireman Harry Cum mings was instantly killed. At a meeting of the Pittsburg mem bers of the Amalgamated Association of Street Car Employes it was determined to present a new wage scale. Mrs. Jefferson Davis is anxious to have the State of Mississippi recognized on the monument to be erected in Rich mond to Jefferson Davis. Proceedings for disbarment have been entered at Marianna, Fla., against for mer Chief Justice Liddon, of the state. Oliver Hopkinson, the oldest member of the Philadelphia bar, is dead, aged 93 years. Two negroes were hanged in Birming ham, Ala., for the murder of their sweet hearts. Grand Chief Warren S. Stone, of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, has ordered the striking motormen on the Interborough to return or be ex pelled. The local leader of the strike says the men will stay out. Many have returned and traffic is moving along. The executive committee of the United Brethren Missionary Board dropped Daniel F. Wilberforce a native African missionary, who, after 25 years work in the church, relapsed to heathenism. W. S. Alley, who was suspended from the New York Stock Exchange for one year for alleged irregularities last Sep tember, has been reinstated by the gov erning committee. The Moral Forces in the Twentieth Century was the subject of the Trask lecture delivered at the Princeton Uni versity by the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale. An address on Some Phases of the Municipal Problem was delivered be fore the Yale Law School.

document.text: The official vote of this State will, it is quite certain, show that the total vote east ht the present election will exceed but little, It any, that in the Cleveland-Harrison con test of 1891 Th official returns haye been reoelred hero at the Capitol from all of the cities and nlnety-flre of the one hundred counties. These give Bryan 157,480, Mc Kinley 129,836, Palmer 2,003, Levering 2,503, Machott socialist 100. It was expected that tho vote of November 8 would largely exceed that of any past campaigns. The re turns, however, show that the Increase will be insignificant. In the returns inode to the secretary of the Commonwealth notice is taken of the largo number of ballots ruined in the preparation and therefore not recog nized In the canvass of the votes. Hon. Page Morris, formerly of Lynchburg, where ho was postmaster nnder President Hayee, was elected to Congress on tho 3d from the Duluth Minn. district as a sound money democrat, beating Mr. Towne, who was elected as a republican two years ago and turned populist, running on the Bryan ticket. The Iron safe was blown open with dynamite and about 0800 In stamps taken and about 100 In currency. Six reg istered packages were In tho safe, but only one wns missing. This was stamps for the Clarksville office, supposed to be 50 . The other live were overlooked. It Is supposed that whsn the door to the safe was blown open the Inside fell on the floor and con cealed them. The thieves gained entrance to the postoffloe by prizing open the door. Several letters, containing dry goods, etc., were opened, bnt the contents were left on the counter. No clue as yet to tho perpetra tors of this theft It Is learned that the present poannt crop Is the poorest for many years, the proportion being but little over half of an average crop. document.text: The Duty of Virginia Freemen. What is the duty of Virginia free men in the present great crises ? Let every voter reflect well before he casts his ballot. It has been rare in the history of this great country that so important an elec tion has engaged the attention of the American people. It is emphat ically a critical crucial period. What is the condition of affairs here at home ? Land in Southside V ir ginia is down to fifty cents an acre in many places and is unsaleable even at that price. I saw in 1895 a tract of land in Buckingham con taining 600 acres sold at less than fifty cents an acre. It was within five miles of a railroad and a mower can be run over every foot of it, and it is fertile and well timbered and in a good neighborhood, convenient to churches and schools. Farm products are below the cost of pro duction. No man wants land be cause he cannot make any profit in cultivating it. What is true of Buckingham is true of every county in Virginia. Indeed Buckingham is far more than an average county, its land is rich and productive and its timber and mineral resources are very great. No farmer can employ a hand even as low as seven dollars a month and find him and make a cent from the sale of farming pro ducts. T h i volume of money in Virginia is less than 5 per capita circulation and is decreasing. Our laborers cannot get employment at any price and thousands of them are forced to emigrate. I cannot tell how many have come to me this year ana said Captain Patteson we are ready to work for you at any price you choose to give. The scarcity of money has filled our highways and byways with tram ps it has filled our prisons and asylums md is still doing its fatal work Despair, misery, want and suffering ire to be seen on eyery side. What the Romaus called the angusta res domi is felt in all sections of the and. Between 1880 and 1890 the population of every agricultural county in Virginia decreased and the decrease has been greater since 1890 than it was before. Buck ham, Cumberland and Fluvanna fell back . enormously. There are fewer white people in Buckingham md Cumberland to-day thau there were one hundred years ago. A s tonishing as is this statement it is true. Actually the beavers are omiug back and building their ams just as they did two centuries go. The trade of the trapper is becoming one of the few profitable employments. This state of things cannot last It is intolerable. I f it continues all over te State a year longer it will force a default in the interest on the Virginia century bonds it will cut down the appro priatiun for the free schools and probably cause their abandonment altogether. It will force the county levies to be lowered and the rate of taxation on land. It will cause the ilaries of officers including county and circuit judges to be cut down one half at least. It will cut down the appropriation for our asylums and will inevitably force a constitu- 1 tional convention. This is no fancy sketch. And yet the people aie asked to vote for William McKinley, and worse still for his allies, the two old dry rotted cats paws, Palmer and Buckner who offer 11 s no hope but propose to continue this dreadful

document.text: The Council, Mayor and Town Manager are still greatly interested in continuing their current Clean- Up Campaign. I want to take this opportunity to again thank Mr Palmer and Mr. Brown and all the employ?.-- State Highway De partment for their untiring efforts and generous assistance in changing the appearance of Main and Court Streets. I also want to thank all of the Town Employees and the people for their support. In order for our Clean-Up Cam paign to be a success we need and solicit the continued cooperation and assistance of all our good citi zens. For the coming week, let s all put our shoulder to the wheel and see that Highland Ave., from the intersection with Court Street to the intersection of Church Street is cleaned and beautified as it should be Remember, this is a job for all of us. Your help is needed. Sincerely, C. T. Moses, Jr., Mayor.

document.text: The Chicago  Eastern Illinois and Illinois Central will build a bridge across the Mississippi River from Grays Point to Thebes. It is stated that the Canadian Pacific will build from Winnipeg to Duluth and compete with Great Northern  and Northern Pacific. The American Sugar Refining Compa ny of New York has been incorporated with a capital of 2.500,000. The direc tors are H. O. Havemeyer, W. E. Thomas, L. M. Palmer, C. N. Senff and A. Donner, of New York city. The English courts have ordered the compulsory winding up of the West Lc Roi, East Le Roi and Columbia-Koote- nay Mining Companies, all Whitaker Wright concerns. The organization of the Northern Se curities Company as. slated in the char ter is only temporary and the permanent board of directors wil be chosen as soon as possible after the election of the Bur lington directors. , Mr. T. J. Hurley, who has for sev eral years-been vice-president and gen eral manager of the Exploration Com pany. of New York, has accepted the presidency of the Mine Securities Cor poration of this city. The capital is 2,500,000.

document.text: The Bureau of Navigation has order ed the ships of the North Atlantic fleet to begin their semi-annual target prac tice in Cope Cod Bay next week. Judge Penfields appointment as spe cial trade commissioner to South Amer ica is regarded as a nice way of getting him out of the State Department. J. Martin Miller, whom the German government would not have as consul at _Aix-la-Chapelle, has been appointed to serve as Auckland. The criminal prosecution of Morris Bursch, contractor, and Robert Charlton, inspector, was ordered by Acting Sec retary of War Oliver. Charlton and Ex aminer F. T. Quinlan are to be dis charged. Judge Advocate General Davis was directed to prepare the necessary papers for this prosecution and submit them to the Department of Justice. Bursch hold a contract with the Quarter masters Department of the Army to fur nish fur caps and gauntlets, to be deliv ered at the Schuylkill Arsenal, Philadel phia. , The Armor Car Lines filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a state ment in which they claim that they are not within the jurisdiction of the com mission. The Board of Consulting Engineers of the Panama Canal Commission agreed to accept the French location at the basis for future detailed discussions. Public Printer F. W. Palmer has been removed and Oscar J. Ricketts, foreman of printing, has been designated to suc ceed- himr Vice President and Mrs. Fairbanks expect to entertain on a large scale dur ing the coming season. An answer was filed to the charges of the Intersate Commerce Commission by the Santa Fe Refrigerator Dispatch, in which the company denied being a com mon carrier. Consul General Rodgers, at Shanghai, cabled that the Chinese boycott of Ameri can goods had been practically abandon ed there. Minister Grip returned with the an nouncement that he would continue to represent Norway and Sweden at Wash ington.
